SEG.ORIGINAL_TEXT: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<headline>
Nepal Earthquake
</headline>
<post id="p1" author="stlveg" datetime="2015-04-25T17:06:00">

I'm not a religious person but for those of you who believe in prayer the Nepali people can sure use some. I sponsor a child in Nepal through the Mitrata Nepal Foundation for Children. Some of the children and families that are helped by MNF have been heard from and are safe. Others we are still waiting to hear.
Please keep them all in your thoughts.
Thank you.
</post>
<post id="p2" author="MoodyJill" datetime="2015-04-25T21:42:00">

I also was very upset about how devastating the earthquake was, and I keep trying to get more information but right now the news cycle seems to be focused on the White House Correspondents' Dinner that it's hard to get updates. Most people are very compassionate and feel the pain of the souls who are suffering when something like this happens. But like you, Gracie, when I heard the news the very first time this morning, my own connections with Nepal entered my mind first, of course, and my thoughts and prayers immediately went all for all of the people in that area that have been oppressed and the Dali Lama had to flee (a hero of mine). And for some reason I've always been fascinated by the yearly Mount Everest summits and follow them every year. Given that May is the month when the weather provides the best possible opportunity to summit Everest, all I could think of is all of the climbers and supporting personnel, including the sherpas, who may have been impacted by this.

But then I read your post her about how you sponsor a child in Nepal. Of course I'll include all of these children and their families in my prayers, but also, I hope and pray that you hear good news soon about the child you're sponsoring. Thank you so much for sharing what you're going through, and if you learn anything further, please keep us posted, okay?
</post>
<post id="p3" author="stlveg" datetime="2015-04-26T13:10:00">
If you can catch a BBC news TV channel they are doing a good job of covering it.
</post>
<post id="p4" author="stlveg" datetime="2015-04-26T15:11:00">
This is the latest news I have from Mitrata Nepal. I did find out our sponsored child Rukesh is OK.
<b>CMHS Boarding School Checks in Safe; More Than 50 Tremors Continue Forcing People to Sleep Outdoors<b>
Minutes ago, Mr. Regmi, Director, of Children's Model Boarding School checked in stating that all of our 25 children living and studying at CMHS are safe.

The children were on a school field trip to Patan (see photo) at the time of the earthquake. In his brief email, Mr. Regmi said they were outside and ran to an open air clearing away from the temples and buildings. Of our children, only Swosthani was injured. A metal piece from the top of a temple cut her leg, which was stitched. Mr. Regmi also sustained a minor injury from a falling brick.
We do not have anything further in terms of where the CMHS children and staff are (i.e., still in Patan or somewhere else) or the status of the school, food and water provisions, etc.

We also heard briefly from Yogesh, Leena's husband. Since the first 7.8 earthquake hit there have been more than 50 aftershocks and tremors. Our staff in Nepal, Leena, Alish, Sushma and their families are sleeping and staying outdoors as the buildings are unsafe and continue to collapse.
Yogesh said that Leena, Alish and Sushma are working tirelessly to find children and their families. Access to internet is near impossible and the cell network is overloaded.
Please keep the children, their families, and our friends in Nepal in your thoughts and prayers. We have so many children and families unaccounted for.
</post>
<post id="p5" author="MoodyJill" datetime="2015-04-26T20:15:00">
<quote orig_author="stlveg">

That's really excellent news that all 25 of the children are safe. It must be SO scary for them (and everyone in Nepal, for that matter) to live with all the aftershocks. Thank you for the update Gracie!
</post>
<post id="p6" author="MoodyJill" datetime="2015-04-26T20:18:00">
Here's a link to an online article about what's been happening on Mt. Everest, but within the article there is another link to 51 photos--heart-breaking, to say the least!

<a href="http://www.cbsnews.com/news/helicopter-needed-for-american-everest-climbing-teams-trapped-by-earthquake/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">http://www.cbsnews.com/news/helicopter-needed-for-american-everest-climbing-teams-trapped-by-earthquake/</a>
</post>
<post id="p7" author="stlveg" datetime="2015-04-26T22:42:00">

It is so very sad. Nepal is a beautiful but very poor country. Many children don't have enough to eat and parents cannot care for them. I am glad to hear that many countries are sending aid of all kinds to help them as they do not have resources.
</post>
<post id="p8" author="MoodyJill" datetime="2015-04-26T23:52:00">

Every time I check the news on my home page, the news just gets worse and worse, Gracie. And you're 100% correct--the country is so poor. But it is also such an amazing country, full of such spiritually-aware and giving people, digging people out of the rumble with their bare hands. Yes, hopefully the countries of the world will continue to reach out and send help
<a href="http://www.cbsnews.com/news/nepal-earthquake-death-toll-continues-to-rise/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">http://www.cbsnews.com/news/nepal-earthquake-death-toll-continues-to-rise/</a>
</post>
<post id="p9" author="stlveg" datetime="2015-04-27T11:38:00">
Here is the latest email from my sister who is in Portugal at this time.
Dear Friends and Family,

As you probably know, Nepal has been hit by a devastating earthquake. The Kathmandu Valley, where the children of Mitrata Nepal Foundation for Children are located has been hit hard. We ( Alexis and the board of directors in St. Louis and I in Portugal) have been trying to locate all the children and families to see if they are safe.Board members have been contacted by some kids on facebook through the safety check, but the infrastructure there, which is already below par, is not functioning.

So far, we have located the children at one of our boarding schools( Children's Model Higher Secondary School) who are safe with some injuries, and a few others but we still do not know if most of the children are ok or not. So there is some relief but still so much worry. It has truly been a heartbreaking and sad time for all of us.
There has been tremendous loss of life in Nepal and people are iving on the street to avoid being in buildings which are not safe. Water and food is in short supply.
Our partner in Nepal has assured us that their staff have survived and they are working hard on finding all the children. They will be in touch with us as soon as they can.

In coming days and weeks, Nepali children and families will be in great need. We have set up a special donation for relief for our children at the www.mitrata.org website. If you are so inclined please help us out. The funds will go first to our children, their families and our staff. If any is left over, we will distribute it locally to responsible relief agencies. Please follow us on facebook at <a href="http://www.facebook.com/mitratanepal" style="line-height:21.3000011444092px;font-weight:inherit;color:rgb(0,104,207);" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">www.facebook.com/mitratanepal</a>

I will be in Nepal again in September with a group of child sponsors and I am sure it will be a changed Nepal. Much of the beautiful temples and cultural areas have been destroyed. Rebuillding will take a long time.
Thank you and pray for our children and beautiful Nepal. The Nepalese are a strong and determined people who with our help will recover. Peace and love,
Christine
</post>
<post id="p10" author="MoodyJill" datetime="2015-04-27T17:20:00">
Thank you SO much, Gracie, for giving us a lead on how to help. The latest things I've been reading online?

The quake was many times more powerful than the 7.0 quake that ruined Haiti in 2010. The quake was a "shallow quake," which took place just five miles beneath the surface and packed about 10 hydrogen bombs' worth of energy. If is had been deeper into the earth, the effect would have been minimal. The city of Katmandu has shifted TEN FEET by the force of this earthquake.
</post>
</doc>
